cmd.cites.cmd.second.line.cite: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information § 3:17

prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: In Gibbons v. Drew Chemical Ltd.,[1] some of the evidence highlighted by the court included the fact that the company was not able to offer evidence to demonstrate that the documents provided to the third party were marked “confidential”. The Gibbons case demonstrates the danger of not clearly marking information as confidential. The information in question included sales and technical manuals, which under normal circumstances should qualify as confidential information, particularly in the face of a covenant not to disclose.

In another case, Chevron Standard Ltd. v. Home Oil Co.,[2] the court concluded that while Leeson, the plaintiff's former chief development geologist, had a general knowledge of some of the information in question, the defendant had not “gained any advantage of confidential information as a result”. The court stated:

On the whole of the evidence I cannot find that Leeson divulged any trade secrets to [the defendant] or any of its employees or agents. Leeson did not disclose to [the corporate defendant] or any of its employees or agents the fact that [the plaintiff] had found seismic anomalies believed to be pinnacle reefs of Upper Devonian age. I am satisfied that Leeson did not know the location of Chevron's anomalies and, further, that he did not reveal to anyone where he thought the anomalies might be located.[3]

It is trite to state that there must be actual personal disclosure to the party sought to be restrained. However, proving such disclosure often comes down to the strength of the evidence and the credibility of the relevant witnesses.[4] The mere acknowledgement that something is confidential does not necessarily make it so.[5] Simply labeling information as “confidential” will not necessarily be sufficient, particularly where most of the information is general public knowledge.[6] However, in a questionable case, where the party receiving the information has been told that it is confidential, such a proviso may place the confider in a stronger position with respect to the determination of whether the relevant information is confidential.[7] By limiting the circumstances under which information is available to others and by marking the information as confidential, an owner will go some distance in establishing confidential status.[8]

On the other hand, classifying information as “non-confidential” has been held as sufficient to confirm that status.[9] The case law has also made it clear that information does not become confidential merely because a contract stipulates that it is confidential.[10]
